per act of parliament |president = |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = [[Paul Mapfumo]] |pro-vice chancellors = |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 140 professors,{{cite web|title=Academic Excellence Rewarded|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/index.php/campus-uz-news/1779-academic-excellence-rewarded|publisher=University of Zimbabwe|accessdate=29 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521185608/http://www.uz.ac.zw/index.php/campus-uz-news/1779-academic-excellence-rewarded|archive-date=21 May 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} 545 [[lecturer]]s, 155 teaching and research assistants (2018) |staff = |students = |undergrad = 17,718 |postgrad = 2681 |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Mount Pleasant, Harare|Mount Pleasant]], [[Harare]] |state = |province = [[Harare Province]] |country = [[Zimbabwe]] |coor = |campus = Urban |former_names = University College of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, University College of Rhodesia, University of Rhodesia, University of Zimbabwe-Rhodesia |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = |colours = |nickname = UZ |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = |website = [http://www.uz.ac.zw/ www.uz.ac.zw] |logo = |footnotes = }} The '''University of Zimbabwe (UZ)''' in [[Harare]], is the oldest and top ranked [[Universities of Zimbabwe|university]] in [[Zimbabwe]]. It was founded through a special relationship with the [[University of London]] and it opened its doors to its first students in 1952. The university has nine faculties and 1 College ( Faculties of Agriculture, Arts, Commerce, Education, Engineering, Law, Science, Social Studies, Veterinary Sciences and the College of Health Sciences) offering a wide variety of degree programmes and many specialist research centres and institutes. The university is accredited through the [[National Council for Higher Education, Zimbabwe|National Council for Higher Education]], under the [[Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education, Zimbabwe|Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education]]. English is the language of instruction. Although once a very successful university, UZ has been facing challenges since 2008 and now the University is on a rebounding drive. Major work is being done to uplift the status of the University. Refurbishments are being carried out on the Main campus and many facilities are being upgraded to make the university an International Academic Brand. The university has faced criticism for awarding fraudulent degrees to members of the [[Mugabe]] regime particularly the obscure PhD given to [[Grace Mugabe]]. == History == ===Early years=== [[File:Uzcouncilroom.jpg|thumb|Council room of the University of Zimbabwe. Portraits of former Vice-Chancellors from left to right: [[Robert Craig (theologian)|Robert Craig]], [[Leonard John Lewis|Leonard Lewis]], [[Walter Kamba]] and [[Gordon Chavunduka]].]] In 1945, Manfred Hodson (after whom a [[University of Zimbabwe#Residences|residence]] is now named) formed the ''Rhodesia University Association'', inspired by the promise of £20,000 by Robert Jeffrey Freeman for establishing such a university. The following year, the Legislative Assembly of [[Southern Rhodesia]] adopted a motion proposed by Hodson for the establishment of a university college to serve the needs of [[Rhodesia]] and neighbouring territories. The [[Governor of Southern Rhodesia]] established the Rhodesia University Foundation Fund in 1947. The Legislative Assembly accepted an offer of land in [[Mount Pleasant, Harare|Mount Pleasant]] from the City of Salisbury (now [[Harare]]) for the construction of the campus in 1948. Four years later a bill was enacted for the incorporation and constitution of the university. First classes began for some 68 students on a temporary site at 147 Baker Avenue (now Nelson Mandela Avenue).{{cite web|last=University of Zimbabwe|first=|authorlink=University of Zimbabwe|title=About UZ|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/information/uz.html|accessdate=2 January 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212230253/http://www.uz.ac.zw/information/uz.html|archivedate=12 December 2008|df=dmy-all}} Independent of the initiatives of Hodson and the Legislative Assembly, the Central African Council's commission on higher education, led by [[Alexander Carr-Saunders|Sir Alexander Carr-Saunders]] (after whom another [[University of Zimbabwe#Residences|residence]] is now named) recommended the establishment of a university college to serve Rhodesia and Nyasaland, with its first preference being to integrate with the Southern Rhodesian initiative. ===Establishment=== Construction began on the Mount Pleasant site, funded by grants from the [[British government|British]] and [[Government of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland|Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] Governments, [[Anglo American Corporation]], the [[British South Africa Company]], the Rhodesia Selection Trust, the [[Alfred Beit#The Beit Trust|Beit Trust]], the [[Ford Foundation]] and the Dulverton Trust and in July 1953 [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Elizabeth, the Queen Mother]] laid the foundation stone. In 1955 the British government formally adopted the institution, establishing the '''University College of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (UCRN)''' by [[Royal Charter]]. The college was admitted to the privilege of Special Relation with the [[University of London]] the following year and in 1957 all activities were transferred to the Mount Pleasant campus. The following year the college was granted pieces of land upon which the [[University of Zimbabwe Farm|college farm]] and the [[University of Zimbabwe Lake Kariba Research Station|Lake Kariba Research Station]] were constructed. In 1963 the [[University of Zimbabwe#Colleges|Medical School]] opened and was affiliated to the [[University of Birmingham]]. After the dissolution of the [[Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]], the University College continued as an independent institution of higher education and research, open to all races. In 1970 a phased termination of the associations with the Universities of London and Birmingham began. ===Post independence=== Following [[Zimbabwe]]'s independence after the [[Rhodesian Bush War]], the university was renamed University of Zimbabwe in 1980. In 1981, the first black Principal, [[Walter Kamba]], was appointed{{cite journal|last=Gaidzanwa|first=R.B.|authorlink=Rudo Gaidzanwa|title=Alienation, Gender and Institutional Culture at the University of Zimbabwe|journal=Feminist Africa|volume=8|pages=60–82|publisher=African Gender Institute|location=Cape Town|year=2007|url=http://www.feministafrica.org/uploads/File/Issue_8/07_issue8_article4.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|pdf]]|issn=1726-4596|accessdate=8 January 2009}}{{cite news|title=Miss Zimbabwe finals postponed|publisher=Associated Press|date=10 September 1981|url=http://digitalnewspapers.libraries.psu.edu/Default/Skins/BasicArch/Client.asp?Skin=BasicArch&&AppName=2&enter=true&BaseHref=DCG/1981/09/10&EntityId=Ar01902|accessdate=8 January 2009}} and in 1982 the Royal Charter was replaced by an Act of Parliament. Student numbers rose from 1,000 in 1980 to 2,000 by 1985.{{cite news|title=Harare makes slow progress|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=22 September 1995|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=95236§ioncode=26|accessdate=8 January 2009}} The [[University of Zimbabwe Act]] was controversially amended in 1990, giving the government more powers and, according to many faculty, students and observers, attacking [[academic freedom]].{{cite web|last=Human Rights Watch|first=|authorlink=Human Rights Watch|title=Human Rights Watch World Report 1990|publisher=|url=https://www.hrw.org/legacy/reports/1990/WR90/AFRICA.BOU-12.htm|accessdate=8 January 2009}}{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe students riot for third day|publisher=St Louis Post-Despatch|date=30 October 1990|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB04CE7293B6B45&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=8 January 2009}} The late 1980s and most of the 1990s saw a rise in [[student protest]],{{cite news|title=A Decade After Winning Independence, Zimbabwe Is at a Crossroads|date=13 May 1990|publisher=Los Angeles Times|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/60054026.html?dids=60054026:60054026&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=May+13%2C+1990&author=NEIL+HENRY&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=A+Decade+After+Winning+Independence%2C+Zimbabwe+Is+at+a+Crossroads+Africa%3A+A+rising+jobless+rate+is+today%27s+most+critical+problem.+But+the+nation+shares+with+others+on+the+continent+the+strains+of+transition+away+from+a+colonial+past.&pqatl=google|accessdate=8 January 2009 | first=Neil | last=Henry}}{{cite news|title=New Zimbabwe party takes aim at Mugabe |publisher=The New York Times|date=7 May 1989|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DEEDB1E38F934A35756C0A96F948260|accessdate=8 January 2009}}{{cite news|title=Protest sets off rioting in Zimbabwe's capital |publisher=The New York Times|date=11 November 1995|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E2D81439F932A25752C1A963958260|accessdate=8 January 2009}} resulting in several closures{{cite news|title=Mugabe Urged to Reopen College |publisher=The New York Times|date=10 October 1989|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DEED91039F933A25753C1A96F948260|accessdate=8 January 2009}} and mass expulsions.{{cite journal|last=Askin |first=S. |authorlink= |title=U. of Zimbabwe Expels Its 10,000 Students After Weeks of Protests Over Tuition Increase |journal=The Chronicle of Higher Education |volume=38 |issue=1 |url=http://chronicle.com/che-data/articles.dir/articles-38.dir/issue-41.dir/41a03702.htm |format=[[abstract (summary)|abstract]] |accessdate=8 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318083915/http://chronicle.com/che-data/articles.dir/articles-38.dir/issue-41.dir/41a03702.htm |archivedate=18 March 2009 }} Despite the ongoing tensions, the university continued to grow and the student population had reached 8,000 by 1995 and 10,139 by 2001. As the 2000s began, the university struggled to meet lecturers' and professors' expectations on salary levels, leading to numerous [[Strike action|strikes]].{{cite news|title=University Strike Ends; Schoolteachers Strike Begins|publisher=The Guardian (UK)|date=10 June 2003|url=http://www.wes.org/ewenr/03May/Africa.htm|accessdate=8 January 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107094737/http://www.wes.org/ewenr/03May/Africa.htm|archivedate=7 January 2009|df=dmy-all}} Many donors, including the [[Government of Sweden]], which had previously been a major financer of UZ, cut or cancelled their aid.{{cite news|title=Aid cuts and fee hike hit Harare|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=3 August 2001|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=164234§ioncode=26|accessdate=8 January 2009}} As the [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|economic crisis]] grew in Zimbabwe, UZ began to fail to recruit lecturers and professors to fill vacancies.{{cite news|title=Economic crisis devastates universities|publisher=University World News|date=25 May 2008|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20080522130127881|accessdate=8 January 2009}} By 2007, the shortage of staff was preventing the teaching and examination of some programmes.{{cite news|title=Student leader takes The University of Zimbabwe(UZ) to High Court |publisher=Harare Tribune|date=12 December 2008|url=http://hararetribune.com/harare-city-zimbabwe/harare-news/1016-student-leader-takes-the-university-of-zimbabweuz-to-high-court.html|accessdate=8 January 2009}} Problems with water and electricity supply, as well as maintenance of infrastructure became critical by the late 2000s. The decline of UZ culminated in the university's failure to re-open for the 2008–2009 academic year.{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe keeps its school doors closed|publisher=The Times (UK)|date=8 January 2009|url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=913512|accessdate=8 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107221948/http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=913512|archive-date=7 January 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The University briefly opened in early 2009, but no classes were held due to strike action by lecturers.{{cite news|title=Health Disaster Looms at UZ |date=24 February 2009|publisher=Radio VOP|url=http://www.radiovop.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5510&Itemid=755|accessdate=25 February 2009}} The institution was closed again in late February, following demonstrations by students against new, hard currency fees.{{cite news|title=University closed following protests|date=22 February 2009|publisher=University World News|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20090220071706173|accessdate=25 February 2009}} ===Controversy over fraudulent degrees=== The university has faced criticism for awarding fraudulent degrees to members of the [[Mugabe]] regime; in 2014, [[Grace Mugabe]] was given a doctorate in sociology, only two months after being registered on the programme, and although a dissertion does not exist in the university archives. Also other senior members of the Mugabe regime were given doctorates, without writing dissertations.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201409191481.html|title=Zimbabwe: Grace Mugabe's PhD Scandal Torches Storm|first=Elias|last=Mambo|date=19 September 2014|publisher=|via=AllAfrica}}{{cite web|url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/entertainment/article/2000135151/zimbabwe-s-first-lady-grace-mugabe-awarded-phd-two-months-after-enrollment|title=Zimbabwe's First Lady Grace Mugabe, awarded PhD, two months after enrollment|first=May|last=Jesaro|website=Standard Digital News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/zimbabwe-grace-mugabe-awarded-phd-two-months-university-where-president-mugabe-chancellor-1465523|title=Zimbabwe: Grace Mugabe Awarded PhD in Two Months from University where President Mugabe is Chancellor|first=Ludovica|last=Iaccino|date=15 September 2014|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theindependent.co.zw/2014/10/24/grace-phd-fraud-interview-sheds-light/|title=Grace PhD fraud: Interview sheds light|date=24 October 2014|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-29451239|title=Call for Zimbabwe's Grace Mugabe to return PhD|date=1 October 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.newsday.co.zw/2014/09/13/now-dr-grace-dr-mujuru/|title=It’s now Dr Grace and Dr Mujuru!|date=13 September 2014|publisher=}} On 20 November 2017, the university of Zimbabwe students boycotted writing exams citing that the former first lady Dr Grace Mugabe's controversial PhD should be revoked. They also protested and declared that they would not write examinations until Robert Mugabe resigned. Inevitably, the 93 year old leader and then chancellor of the University resigned the following afternoon on 21 November 2017 as head of state and government. Many claimed that the University of Zimbabwe's students will go down in history as those who gave the Mugabe regime the 'final push' of his 37 year reigned as Zimbabwe's leader{{Citation needed|reason=Where is the source on this?|date=December 2017}}. ==Academics== ===Undergraduate=== [[File:uz geology fieldschool2002.jpg|thumb|left|Undergraduate [[geology]] [[field work|field school]] in [[Mazowe District]], Bachelor of [[Science]] programme, University of Zimbabwe.]] The basic format of undergraduate learning at UZ is [[lecture]]s, by [[professor]]s or [[lecturer]]s and [[tutorial]]s by [[lecturer]]s of [[teaching assistant]]s. Many programmes also have [[laboratory]]-based practical work and [[field work|field school]]s. Tests and assignments on course content are graded for a theory [[coursework]] grade. Practical work, where applicable, is graded for a practical coursework grade. Theory, and in some cases practical, [[Test (assessment)|examination]]s are administered. The degree programmes follow the [[Course (education)|Course Unit]] model, and in many programmes it is possible for students to select some of the courses from a range of options. Honours degrees have a compulsory project course that the students must complete individually, with different projects carried out by each student.University of Zimbabwe Academic Registry. (2005) ''General Academic Regulations for Undergraduate Degrees of the University of Zimbabwe''. The undergraduate programmes offered lead to [[Bachelor degree|Bachelor]], [[Bachelor degree#Honours Degrees and academic distinctions|Bachelor (Honours)]] and Intercalated bachelor's degrees. Registered bachelor's degree programmes are in arts, business studies and computer science, tourism and hospitality management, education, adult education, science education, nursing science, science, social work, dental surgery, medicine and surgery and veterinary science. Registered undergraduate Bachelor (Honours) programmes are in agriculture, agricultural engineering, applied environmental science, arts, accountancy, business studies, law, engineering, mining engineering, surveying, medical laboratory sciences, nursing science, pharmacy, occupational therapy, physiotherapy, science, economics, politics and administration, psychology, rural and urban planning, and sociology. Registered intercalated programmes are in anatomy, human physiology, veterinary anatomy, veterinary physiology and veterinary biochemistry.{{cite web|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw|title=Undergraduate Prospectus of the University of Zimbabwe|last=University of Zimbabwe|first=|authorlink=University of Zimbabwe|year=2006|accessdate=2 January 2009}} ===Postgraduate=== [[File:2004 uz iwrm.jpg|thumb|Postgraduate [[water resources]] students in the Faculty of Engineering, University of Zimbabwe, with their [[professor]]s and [[lecturer]]s.]] The University of Zimbabwe offers postgraduate honours degrees, two types of master's degree and doctoral degrees. Postgraduate honours programmes, also known as ''special honours'' programmes last are for one-year duration and incorporate coursework, examinations and a compulsory project module. Master's degrees by coursework and project are designated M.A. or M.Sc. and are of one to two years duration. They incorporate coursework and project modules. Master's degrees by research thesis only are designated M.Phil. and require a minimum of two years study. The doctoral programme, D.Phil., is by research thesis only. Students who are carrying out an M.Phil. study, but have not yet submitted their thesis, may apply to their faculty to upgrade their study to the D.Phil. programme.{{cite web|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw|title=Postgraduate Prospectus of the University of Zimbabwe|last=University of Zimbabwe|first=|authorlink=University of Zimbabwe|year=2006|accessdate=2 January 2009}} ===Suspension of programmes=== Due to the heavy staff vacancies that UZ began suffering from in the 2000s, many programmes and specialisations have been suspended. === Rankings === Although UZ has not generally featured in major international rankings such as the [[THES - QS World University Rankings|Times Higher Education Supplement QS World University Rankings]] or the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]], the World Universities Ranking placed the university number 14 in Africa in 2007, after various South African universities, the [[American University in Cairo]] and the [[University of Dar-es-Salaam]], and number 3,549 out of 9,760 accredited universities in the world.{{cite news|url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/137640/1/ghanaian-universities-fail-in-world-ranking.html|title=Ghanaian universities fail in world ranking|date=13 June 2007|accessdate=7 January 2009|publisher=Ghana News}} By 2008, UZ had slid to number 17 in Africa and number 4,001 globally.{{cite web|url=http://www.webometrics.info/top100_continent.asp?cont=africa|title=World universities ranking: top Africa|last=|publisher=Ranking web of world universities|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004092257/http://www.webometrics.info/top100_continent.asp?cont=africa|archivedate=4 October 2009|deadurl=yes|accessdate=7 January 2009|df=dmy-all}} In 2010, according to [[University Ranking by Academic Performance (URAP)]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.urapcenter.org/2010|title=URAP - University Ranking by Academic Performance}} University of Zimbabwe is the best university in Zimbabwe and 1340th university in the world. ==Campuses== [[File:Uzgreen.jpg|thumb|left|Social gathering on the edge of the College Green, University of Zimbabwe]] The main campus of the University of Zimbabwe is located in the [[Mount Pleasant, Harare|Mount Pleasant]] suburb in northern [[Harare]]. It forms the main portion of the block of land reserved for educational purposes between Mount Pleasant Drive, Upper East Road, Churchill Avenue and Teviotdale Road. Other facilities within this area include the [[Zimbabwe Schools Examination Council]], the [[Ministry of Education, Sports and Culture (Zimbabwe)|Ministry of Education, Sports and Culture]] Audio-Visual Centre and [[Mount Pleasant School, Harare|Mount Pleasant School]].{{cite map|publisher=Surveyor General, Zimbabwe|title=Street Map of Harare|cartography=|edition=2002|section=}} In addition to the academic buildings, the main campus is host to sporting facilities, all but two student residences and much of the staff housing. The College Green, located centrally to the academic buildings, is a popular site for social events. About one third of the campus is a seasonal [[wetland]], unsuitable for construction and thus unused.{{cite map|publisher=University of Zimbabwe Department of Physical Planning|title=Map of the University of Zimbabwe|cartography=|edition=2000|section=}} The major satellite campus is the Medical School campus at [[Parirenyatwa Hospital]] in central Harare. It houses the College of Health Sciences. Additional university properties within Harare include blocks of [[apartments|flats]] for staff and student housing in [[Avondale, Harare|Avondale]], [[Avenues, Harare|the Avenues]] and Mount Pleasant. The university also owns a [[University of Zimbabwe Farm|farm]] in Teviotdale, [[Mazowe District]], north of Harare{{cite map|publisher=Surveyor General, Zimbabwe|title=1:250,0000 Series: Harare|cartography=|edition=1998|section=}} and the [[University of Zimbabwe Lake Kariba Research Station]] in the Nyamhunga suburb of [[Kariba, Zimbabwe|Kariba]].{{cite map|publisher=Surveyor General, Zimbabwe|title=1:250,0000 Series: Kariba|cartography=|edition=1998|section=}} Several of Zimbabwe's universities started as colleges and satellite campuses of UZ, including [[Bindura University of Science Education]] and [[Chinhoyi University of Technology]]. == Administration and organisation == ===Central governance=== {{See also|List of principals of the University of Zimbabwe}} The titular head of the university is the [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]], who is the [[President of Zimbabwe]]. The university is governed by a [[University Council]], comprising the university's chief officers, representatives of the Senate, staff and students, nominees of the Minister of Higher and Tertiary Education and representatives form various sectors of commerce and civil society. The chief executive of the university is the [[Vice-Chancellor]], who is appointed by the Chancellor after consultation with the Minister of Higher and Tertiary Education and the University Council. The Vice-Chancellor is assisted by one or more [[Pro–Vice-Chancellor|Pro–Vice-Chancellors]], appointed by the University Council with the approval of the Minister of Higher and Tertiary Education.{{cite web|url=http://www.parlzim.gov.zw/acts-list/university-of-zimbabwe-act-25-16|title=University of Zimbabwe Act (Chapter 25:16)|publisher=[[Parliament of Zimbabwe]]|accessdate=25 August 2018}} The academic authority of the university is vested in the [[Academic Senate|Senate]], comprising the university's chief officers, the [[Dean (education)|deans of faculties]], all full [[professor]]s, the chairmen of departments and staff and student representatives. The university is divided into [[Faculty (division)|faculties]], managed by an executive dean and governed by a Faculty Board comprising all professors and [[lecturer]]s. ===Faculties=== There are ten academic faculties: {| class="wikitable table" |- ! However, many of Zimbabwe's public universities started as colleges of the University of Zimbabwe: {| class="wikitable table" |- ! Former college of the University of Zimbabwe ! Current University |- | Bindura University College for Science Education | [[Bindura University of Science Education]] |- | Chinhoyi University College | [[Chinhoyi University of Technology]] |- | University College of Distance Education{{cite web|title=Higher Education and Open and Distance Education as a Strategy for National Development: the ZOU Case|last=Kurasha|first=P.|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|year=2006|url=http://portal.unesco.org/education/en/files/52554/11725003185Kurasha.pdf/Kurasha.pdf|accessdate=5 January 2009}} | [[Zimbabwe Open University]] |- |} [[File:2005 uz eng graduation.jpg|thumb|Faculty of Engineering graduation ceremony, University of Zimbabwe, August 2005.]] ===Trans-disciplinary institutes=== The university has two trans-disciplinary research institutes: the Institute of Development Studies (IDS) and the Institute of Environmental Studies (IES). ===Affiliated institutions=== There are numerous education institutions affiliated to the University of Zimbabwe, including teacher training colleges and the School of Social Work. ===Academic year=== The academic year runs from August to June, with [[graduation]] normally in September. As from February 2016, the University introduced a second intake,with an academic year that runs from February to December. ==Student life== [[File:Benjani Mwaruwari Manchester City v. Arsenal 1.png|100px|thumb|left|[[Benjani Mwaruwari]] played [[Football (soccer)|football]] at the University of Zimbabwe.]] ===Residences=== On the main campus there are five residences for women: Swinton Hall, Complexes 1, 4 and 5 and Carr-Saunders, and four residences for men: Manfred Hodson Hall, Complex 2, Complex 3 and Manfred Hodson Annex (formerly New Hall). There is also the Medical Residence at the Medical School campus and Mount Royal Residence in the [[Avenues, Harare|Avenues]], in central Harare. The residences were closed in June 2007, with the university authorities citing maintenance and sanitation problems but were reopened in 2014. === Sports, clubs and traditions === The university has a target of at least one current or former UZ student representing the country in a medal winning sports team in international competitions annually.{{cite book|last=University of Zimbabwe|first=|authorlink=University of Zimbabwe|title=The University of Zimbabwe 5–Year Strategic Plan, 2003–2007|year=2003}} [[Sport]] at UZ is centred around the Sports Pavilion, which was donated by National Breweries.{{cite web|last=University of Zimbabwe |first= |authorlink=University of Zimbabwe |title=Historical Note |work= |url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/admini/registry/downloads/00-Prelims1a-Historical%20.pdfDate= |author= |publisher=University of Zimbabwe |accessdate=4 January 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Sports offered at the university include [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[basketball]], [[cricket]], [[Football (soccer)|football]], [[hockey]], [[Rugby union|rugby]] and [[tennis]]. UZ has frequently won the Zimbabwe Universities Sports Association Games.{{cite news|title=Every Monday|date=17 May 2004|publisher=|accessdate=9 January 2009|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/monday/everyful.php?recordID=25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316020328/http://www.uz.ac.zw/monday/everyful.php?recordID=25|archive-date=16 March 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In its early years, men's hockey was the premier sport, with a team in Salisbury's "First League" in 1960''The Rhodesia Herald'' (Daily), 1960 The University of Zimbabwe Football Club plays in Zimbabwe's Division two and is the former home of [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] [[Striker (association football)|striker]] and [[Zimbabwe national football team]] captain, [[Benjani Mwaruwari]].{{cite news|title=Benjani Mwaruwari:::::Who is Who in Zimbabwe |date=13 June 2008 |publisher=Nehanda Radio |url=http://www.nehandaradio.com/zimbabwe/whoiswho/sports/benjani.html |accessdate=9 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106053711/http://nehandaradio.com/zimbabwe/whoiswho/sports/benjani.html |archivedate=6 January 2010 }} The club was for a time coached by former [[President of Zimbabwe|President]] [[Canaan Banana]].{{cite news|title=Canaan Banana|date=11 November 2003|publisher=The Telegraph (UK)|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1446451/Canaan-Banana.html|accessdate=9 January 2009 | location=London}} When Zimbabwe hosted the [[All-Africa Games]] in 1995, UZ was the games village.{{cite news|title=Govt constitutes All Africa Games Committee|date=30 November 2007|publisher=Lusaka Times|url=http://www.lusakatimes.com/?p=1628|accessdate=9 January 2009}} Maintenance of sporting facilities is the responsibility of the Director: Sport, but in recent years accessing funds from the State Procurement Board has been a challenge. Other popular and successful sporting disciplines at UZ are Basketball, Vollyeball, Rugby and Handball whom are all playing in the Harare professional leagues. In October 2015, the Sports Department organised a Handball festival in celebration of the University's 6oth anniversary and this festival has become an annual event ever since and the biggest handball festival in the country. In most departments there are subject–related clubs or societies, for example the Kirk Biological Society{{cite web|last=Ndebele |first=M.R. |title=Career links page |url=http://aslo.org/career/careerlink/archive/January-42.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20090315011949/http://aslo.org/career/careerlink/archive/January-42.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 March 2009 |publisher=American Limnological Society |accessdate=7 January 2009 }} and the [[AIESEC]] and Students Institution for Success Club.{{cite web|last=|first=|title=UZ Careers Exhibition 2005|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/units/dcas/UZ%20Careers%20Exhibition%202005.doc|publisher=University of Zimbabwe|accessdate=7 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327140708/http://www.uz.ac.zw/units/dcas/UZ%20Careers%20Exhibition%202005.doc|archive-date=27 March 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 2005, UZ won the Students in Free Enterprise World Cup held in Ontario, Canada. There are also non–academic clubs such as [[Rotaract]]{{cite news|title=Every Monday|date=11 June 2007|publisher=University of Zimbabwe|url=http://www.uz.ac.zw/monday/everyful.php?recordID=25|accessdate=7 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316020328/http://www.uz.ac.zw/monday/everyful.php?recordID=25|archive-date=16 March 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} === Gender issues === The gender gap in enrollment at UZ, like at African universities,{{cite news|title=Female scholars' suffering revealed|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=1 April 2005|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=195097§ioncode=26|accessdate=8 January 2009}} became a concern by the mid-1990s and in 1995 an affirmative action programme was built into the university's policy.{{cite news|title=Affirmative Action Overdue in Zimbabwe|publisher=IPS|date=7 March 1995|url=http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/37/014.html|accessdate=8 January 2009}} However, many female students feel inhibited from taking male-dominated courses or taking part in student politics. Women are intimidated by gender–related violence and sexual exploitation.{{cite news|title=Student dies over ''sugar daddies''|publisher=The Telegraph (UK)|date=21 June 2001|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/1310897/Student-dies-over-sugar-daddies.html|accessdate=8 January 2009 | location=London | first=David | last=Blair}} ==University of Zimbabwe people== === Vice–Chancellors and principals and leadership in the SRC post 2001 === {{See also|List of principals of the University of Zimbabwe}} The first chief executive of the university was [[William Rollo]], who served as interim principal from 1953 to 1955. The first substantive Principal was [[Sir Walter Adams]] who served from 1955 to 1966 and was later Director of the [[London School of Economics]]. Sir Walter was succeeded by [[Terence Miller|Professor Terence Miller]], who lasted a mere two years as his political views brought him into conflict with the [[Unilateral Declaration of Independence (Rhodesia)#Government of Rhodesia|government]].{{cite web|last=Gale|first=W.D.|title=Rhodesia: History|year=1970|url=http://www.rhodesia.nl/rally.htm|accessdate=7 January 2009}} His successor, [[Robert Craig (theologian)|Robert Craig]], later [[Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland]], served from 1969 to 1980.{{cite news|title=The Very Rev Professor Robert Craig|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4699093.html|date=8 February 1995|publisher=The Independent (UK)|accessdate=7 January 2009}} [[Leonard John Lewis|Professor Leonard J Lewis]] served as Principal for the transition to Zimbabwe's independence, despite his somewhat controversial views on African education and politics.{{cite journal|last=Challiss|first=R.J.|title=Phelps–Stokesism and education in Zimbabwe|journal=Zambezia|volume=11|pages=109–125|url=http://archive.lib.msu.edu/DMC/African%20Journals/pdfs/Journal%20of%20the%20University%20of%20Zimbabwe/vol11n2/juz011002005.pdf|publisher=University of Zimbabwe|location=Harare|issn=0379-0622}} He was succeeded in 1981 by [[Walter Kamba|Professor Walter G Kamba]], who became Vice–Chancellor when that post was created to replace that of Principal. Like Prof Miller, Prof Kamba came into conflict with the [[Government of Zimbabwe|government]] and he resigned in a controversial speech at the 1992 graduation ceremony, citing government interference and threats to [[academic freedom]].{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=167662§ioncode=26|title=Campus shuts to students over polls|date=8 March 2002|publisher=Times Higher Education Supplement (UK)|accessdate=4 January 2009}} He was succeeded by [[Gordon Chavunduka|Professor Gordon L Chavunduka]] (1992–1996), who was followed by [[Graham Hill (academic)|Professor FW Graham Hill]] (1997–2002). The incumbent Vice–Chancellor, [[Levi Nyagura|Professor Levi M Nyagura]] has served since 2003.{{cite web |url=http://www2.uz.ac.zw/index.php/aboutus/administration/327-vice-chancellor.html |title= Vice Chancellor|work=www2.uz.ac.zw|publisher=University of Zimbabwe| accessdate= 20 December 2011}} ===Notable faculty=== {{Main|List of University of Zimbabwe people#Faculty}} === Notable alumni === {{Main|List of University of Zimbabwe people#Alumni}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Portal|Zimbabwe|Universities}} {{commons category}} * {{official|http://www.uz.ac.zw/ }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110612093405/http://www.uz.ac.zw/medicine/index.html College of Health Sciences] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090211221104/http://www.ies.ac.zw/ Institute of Environmental Studies] * [http://www.brti.co.zw/ Biomedical Research and Training Institute] * [http://www.africanbookscollective.com/publishers/university-of-zimbabwe-publications UZ Publications] * [http://www.sarua.org/?q=uni_University+of+Zimbabwe Southern African Regional Universities Association entry for UZ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071202043446/http://uzweb.uz.ac.zw/medicine/ichedu/howto.html Institute of Continuing Health Education] {{Universities in Zimbabwe|state=autocollapse}} {{Vice–Chancellors and principals of the University of Zimbabwe |state=autocollapse}} {{coord|17.784|S|31.053|E|display=title|source:dewiki}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zimbabwe, University Of}} [[Category:University of Zimbabwe|*]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Zimbabwe|University of Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Education in Harare|University of Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1952]] [[Category:1952 establishments in Southern Rhodesia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Harare]]
